questions.text: Ear Ossicular development is completed by
questions.solution: Ossicles at 20 weeks of prenatal life were cartilagenous, and at 24 weeks they were ossified and surrounded by mesenchyme. Postnatal changes were minimal. These parameters of Ossicles will help in designing of implants and treating hearing loss. mucous membrane

questions.text: Parents of 2 yrs female child with suspected B/L profound hearing loss attended ENT OPD for cochlear implantation. Main investigation prior to surgery is
questions.solution: It performed if a newborn or infant fails the hearing screening test given in the hospital shortly after birth, or for older children if there is a suspicion of hearing loss that was not confirmed through more conventional hearing tests. The BERA test is safe and does not hurt.

questions.text: Name the device?
VEMP checks integrity of which nerve
questions.solution: Vestibular evoked myogenic potentials (VEMP) are a new method to establish the functional status of the otolith organs. The sacculocollic reflex of the cervical VEMP to air conduction (AC) reflects predominantly saccular function due to saccular afferents to the inferior vestibular nerve.

questions.text: Cookie bite audiogram is seen in which of the following disease?
questions.solution: The typical pattern of cochlear otosclerosis in the early stages is the “cookie bite” pattern, where the greatest degree of hearing loss occurs in the midfrequency hearing range and is characteristically a mixed hearing loss. Tinnitus is usually present in a large percentage of patients.

questions.text: In audiogram, symbol (X) is used to mark
questions.solution: Air conduction testing results are indicated with a red “O” for the right ear and a blue “X” for the left ear. Bone conduction testing is indicated with the symbols “[“ or “<”.

choices.text: Adenoidectomy with or without grommet insertion

questions.text: 10 yrs child presented to ENT OPD with history of mouth breathing for last 3 yrs. Otoscopy revealed B/L retracted TM with air fluid level inside with high conductive hearing loss. Most appropriate treatment is
All are treatment modalities for sudden sensorineural hearing loss, Except?
questions.solution: The resulting hearing loss may be temporary in some people but has proven to be permanent in others. In addition, Botulinum treatments can result in tinnitus, and some balance problems such as dizziness and vertigo.

questions.text: 26 yrs male presented to ENT OPD History of right sided hearing loss with recurrent facial twitching. Tympanic membrane was normal.PTA-40/50 Rt side, SDS-30 Percent. MRI Brain s/o hypointense T1,hyperintense T2, gadolinium non enhancing CP angle Lesion. Suspected diagnosis is
questions.solution: Epidermoids are one of the rare benign, congenital, developmental tumors, usually located in the cerebellopontine angle and parasellar regions. They cause various symptoms, especially ones in the cerebellopontine angle. These symptoms could be associated with cerebellar signs (ataxia), increased intracranial pressure (headache, nausea, vomiting) or cranial nerve disturbances (hearing loss or tinnitus, facial nerve palsy, trigeminal neuralgia, etc.). Herein, we report on a patient with a cerebellopontine angle epidermoid cyst having HS as the sole presenting complaint.

questions.text: A patient has U/L progressive and fluctuant SNHL and displacusis. Diagnosis is
questions.solution: Meniere, is a progressive disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of spontaneous vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus, often with a feeling of fullness in the ear. The characteristic of the disease is that it is an unpredictable, fluctuating illness with noteworthy hidden disability.

questions.text: 30/M started experiencing dizziness after a history of fall. Patient could hear his own heartbeat in the ear, with the dizziness increasing on loud noise exposure and blowing the nose. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
SCDS is a rare condition caused by an abnormal thinness or incomplete closure of one of the bony canals in the inner ear.

The problem can cause hearing loss, sound distortion and balance problems triggered by loud noises or intracranial pressure caused by sneezing or coughing.

Patients often hear internal sounds - their voice, pulse, chewing, eyes moving — or their footsteps in the affected ear.

Symptoms may appear spontaneously or after a trauma or other incident that breaks the abnormally fragile canal.

SCDS warrants a visit to a specialist who can assess this unusual disorder, and, if necessary, treat it with surgery

questions.text: A 6 yrs male child presented to ENT emergency with left ear profuse ear discharge for last 3 days with lateral and forward displacement of pinna. X ray mastoid revealed destruction of cotical septations. Diagnosis is
questions.solution: Acute Coalescent Mastoiditis (most common presentation): Inflammation of the epithelial lining with erosion through the boney septations of the mastoid air cells. This erosion can progress to intracavity abscess formation, which can extend further to adjacent structures.

questions.text: All of the following are steps in Stapedotomy except
Conductive deafness in longitudinal temporal bone fracture may be due to:
questions.solution: Longitudinal temporal bone fractures are more common than the transverse type. Conductive hearing loss in can be due to middle ear hemorrhage, or as in this case due to ossicular chain disruption. In any case of temporal bone fracture, ossicular joint alignments should be assessed

questions.text: Labyrinthine fistula can be diagnosed by
questions.solution: A labyrinthine fistula may be created by repeated and insidious infection of a mastoid cavity that has been exposed to the outside during canal wall down surgery. Intensive care of the opened mastoid cavity is essential to avoid this late complication. the presence of vertigo and/or a positive fistula test, as well as sensorineural hearing loss, should raise the suspicion for a fistula.

questions.text: Skull base osteomyelitis is characterised by all except
questions.solution: the radiographic appearance is highly variable and can include an almost normal-looking bone, a focal lytic lesion with geographic margins, a mixed sclerotic-lytic lesion, or a diffusely permeative process with cortical destruction and soft-tissue involvement An important feature is the presence of a bone sequestrum in the lesion, Surgical debridement might be necessary in specific cases, including those with extensive soft tissue involvement, severe pain despite antibiotic treatment, complications (abscess formation), or bone sequestrum, as well as refractory cases. Other management approaches for complications, such as endovascular therapy for pseudoaneurysms and anticoagulant therapy for venous sinus thrombosis, should be individualized.

questions.text: Which is the objective test of choice in assessing hearing in neonates?
questions.solution: Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (BERA) is a simple, noninvasive, objective test for early identification of hearing impairment in children and neonates. It can be used as a screening test and is useful in newborns, infants, and other difficult-to-test patients.

questions.text: Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma occurs in which of the following entities
questions.solution:
blast injury (BI) defines clinical states, such as external ear injury, tympanic membrane perforation, ossicular chain damage, or acquired cholesteatoma that develop due to foreign bodies, including dust, gunpowder, and shrapnel pieces, which spread around in explosion. In case of a primary or secondary injury, damage can occur in the external ear, tympanic membrane, middle ear, or inner ear.

In our study, otological injuries, which were not a part of multi-trauma and resulted from handmade, explosive-induced blast trauma were examined and discussed in light of literature. This was aimed to contribute to the experience of our colleagues by sharing findings developed in exceptional circumstances.

questions.text: 50 yrs old male presented to ENT Opd with Rt nasal obs with epistaxis For last 6 mths only , biopsy suggestive of tumor showing stromal infiltration. CT shows no bony erosion or intraorbital extension. Likely diagnosis is
questions.solution: Ringertz tumour  presented with complaints of nasal blockage, which progressively increased over time and nasal discharge since one and half years with occasional history of epistaxis. On anterior rhinoscopic examination, there was a fleshy polypoidal mass filling the right nasal cavity. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography revealed a soft tissue density mass filling maxillary sinus and posterior choana with mild enhancement. Endoscopic medial maxillectomy was performed with complete removal of mass.

questions.text: A Pt who works in rice paddy fields presented to emergency with epistaxis and nasal obstruction for last 2yrs. Examination was suggestive of pinkish nasal mass studded with whitish dots. Diagnosis is
questions.solution: Nasal rhinosporidiosis may present with unilateral nasal obstruction or epistaxis. Other symptoms may include local pruritus, coryza with sneezing, rhinorrhea, and postnasal discharge (drip) with cough. Patients often report a sensation that a foreign body is present in their nasal canal.

questions.text: Investigation of choice to diagnose CSF rhinorrhoea is
questions.solution: MR cisternography is a non-invasive technique that can detect CSF fistula in multiple planes without the disadvantage of lumbar puncture and ionizing radiation. On the T2 weighted fast spin echo, the inherent bright signal of CSF is well seen against the black background of bone and air in paranasal sinus

questions.text: Which of the following technique used for Tonsillectomy works on creation of plasma field
questions.solution: Coblation is an example of high?frequency electrosurgery. The technique involves passing radiofrequency energy through a conductive medium (such as isotonic sodium chloride) producing a plasma field. The resultant energetic charge?carrying ions have sufficient energy to break organic molecular bonds, resulting in low?temperature (40ºC to 70ºC compared with > 100ºC in electrosurgery) molecular disintegration of the tissue. A bipolar probe, known as a coblation wand, is used to accomplish the dissection. The plasma field has a radius of about 100μm-200μm around the electrodes and is kept stable within the head of the coblation wand by the continuous supply of saline. Furthermore, the plasma field is controlled by the bipolar energy between the negative and positive ions that are produced by the plasma in order to use a precise amount of plasma to prevent damaging healthy tissues around the tonsils.

questions.text: Identify X ray view
70 yrs diabetic male presented with foul smelling nasal discharge with blackish discoloration of hard palate for 2 days, fasting blood sugar is 400mg%. Next important investigation is
questions.solution: Diabetes with rhino-orbital-cerebral (ROC) mucormycosis is a medical and surgical emergency. A high index of suspicion is critical for diagnosis, and early initiation of therapy often before confirmation of the diagnosis is necessary to optimize the outcomes. Such patients require extensive debridement surgery, under cover of intravenous (IV) amphotericin B.

questions.text: Potts puffy tumour is a complication of
questions.solution: Pott's puffy tumour (PPT) is a known complication of frontal sinusitis. It is defined as subperiosteal abscess formation due to osteomyelitis of the frontal bone presenting as a forehead swelling. It is a life-threatening condition that can lead to intracranial and intraorbital complications

choices.text: due to persistence of bucconasal membrane
Mc govern technique is also used
surgery by transnasal or transpalatal approach

questions.text: All are true about choanal atresia except
questions.solution: Unilateral choanal atresia, the most common form, is often seen without accompanying congenital defects and may not be diagnosed at the time of delivery. Bilateral choanal atresia almost always occurs in the presence of other congenital defects.

choices.text: Steroid and Caldwell luc operation is mainstay of treatment
Site of Attachment is anterolateral wall of maxilla.

questions.text: All are true about AC polyp except
questions.solution: Antrochoanal polyps (ACPs) are benign polypoid lesions arising from the maxillary antrum and they extend into the choana. They occur more commonly in children and young adults, and they are almost always unilateral. The etiopathogenesis of ACPs is not clear

questions.text: All of the following are removed in radical neck dissection except
questions.solution: Important extra-nodal structures such as the spinal accessory nerve, internal jugular vein and sternocleidomastoid muscle are sacrificed. Post- auricular, CN 10, periparotid, suboccipital, perifacial, buccinator, retropharyngeal and paratracheal nodes are not removed in this nodal dissection.

questions.text: All are diagnostic criteria of ARFS except
questions.solution:
ARFS is seen only in allergic mucin nasal polyposis

type 1 hypersensitivity

questions.text: Aseptate hyphae with Right angle branching is a characteristic feature of which fungal sinusitis
questions.solution: The fungal forms of mucormycosis are broad, non-septate hyphae. They are wider than Aspergillus species and branch irregularly. The angle of branching is greater than other organisms, and usually approaches 90°

questions.text: The incision used in postaural approach to the ear is?
questions.solution: An obsolete procedure for relief of mastoiditis, consisting of a retroauricular incision into the mastoid bone. Post-aural or William Wilde's incision is extremely versatile, providing good access to the middle ear, even in patients with a narrow external auditory canal and short neck.

choices.text: Egg shell crackling can be elicited
Displaces the eyeball downward and laterally

questions.text: All are true regarding mucocele of frontal sinus except?
questions.solution: frontal sinus show Egg shell crackling can be elicited Displaces the eyeball downward and laterally Treatment is front ethmoidectomy

questions.text: Most possible diagnosis from following picture of direct laryngoscopy is
A 6 yrs pt presented to ENT OPD with history of mouth breathing for last 3 months. Oral examination revealed pale grape like structure hanging from pos choana. Etiology is possibly related to
Most common presentationin nasopharyngeal carcinoma is
questions.solution: The four most common symptoms in order of frequencies were cervical lymphadenopathy, epistaxis, hearing loss and diplopia. 80.8% of the patients presented with cervical lymphadenopathy and about 85% of the patients presented in the advanced stages. Like most other squamous cell carcinomas (SCC) of the head and neck primaries, lymphatic drainage of the nasopharynx is predominantly to the cervical lymph nodes. However, NPC has the highest preponderance for regional lymph node metastasis among head and neck SCC

questions.text: Nasal Angiofibroma is characterized by all except
HPV do not cause which type of carcinoma
questions.solution: HPV causes, Laryngeal Ca, Tonsillar Ca and Base of tongue Ca

questions.text: Spasmodic Dysphonia can be corrected by doing:
questions.solution: Type II Thyroplasty is a surgical procedure that separates the vocal folds and it is used to treat the adductor form of spasmodic dysphonia. It is reasoned that speaking in those with AdSD is affected due to the tight closure of the vocal folds during speech.

questions.text: Injury to superior laryngeal nerve causes
High tracheostomy is indicated in
questions.solution: In cases of laryngeal cancer the incision was usually made between the 1st and 2nd tracheal rings. With the help of tracheal dilator forceps, appropriate sized tracheostomy tubes were inserted and adequately secured to the patients’ necks. The standardized post-operative tracheostomy care was followed in all cases.

questions.text: Laser used in laryngeal surgeries is

choices.text: As type of curve on tympanometry

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of otosclerosis
Type 3 laser cordectomy is
Kashima operation is done for
questions.solution: Endoscopic laser cordectomy, also known as Kashima operation, is an endoscopic laser surgical procedure performed for treating the respiratory difficulty caused as a result of bilateral abductor vocal fold paralysis.

questions.text: Preferred treatment of verrucous CA larynx T1N0M0 is
questions.solution: conventional supraglottic laryngectomy has been replaced by transoral laser surgery in many cases. The functional and oncological results of these two surgical techniques can be compared, but the endoscopic approach of transoral laser surgery offers functional advantages

questions.text: 50 yrs male presented to ENT emergency with dysphagia, tortocollis,Left sided neck swelling for 1 day. There is H/O alcohol intake along with fish. Diagnosis is
questions.solution: Retropharyngeal abscess seldom occur in adults and if it does so, a search for a prior dental procedure, trauma, head and neck infection is needed. The symptoms may include neck pain, dysphagia, sore throat, and in rare cases, dyspnea accompanied by stridor.

choices.text: speech therapy and PPI are mainstay of treatment

questions.text: All are true about reinke odema except
questions.solution: While surgical microlarynscopy has its associated risks, if left untreated, Reinke's edema can lead to a variety of long-term complications.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for stage 3 ca Larynx is
questions.solution: Concurrent chemoradiation (CTRT) is the standard treatment in stage III and IV laryngeal cancer with intact cartilage and functional larynx. Patients with cartilage destruction or dysfunctional larynx are not the candidates for organ preservation

questions.text: Gutzmann pressure test is used to diagnose
questions.solution: gutzmann's pressure test in brief? Puberphonia is persistence of high pitched voice,even after puberty,in the absence of any organic cause.To treat it,Gutzmann's pressure test can be done. Ask the patient to hold the thyroid cartilage downward and backward to relax vocal cord and produce low tone voice.

questions.text: Cidofovir is used in JORP( Juvenile onset respiratory papillomatosis) as
questions.solution: cidofovir was effective in the treatment of generalised molluscum contagiosum in 2 children with AIDS. The lesions were treated with topical application of 3% cidofovir once a day, 5 days a week, for 8 weeks.
